abstract.p: Photo of floral artist Olivier Guigni in his own colorful clothing (Pulse column) (S)

block.p: Long before Palm Beach colors became the shades of the season, Olivier Guigni, a floral artist, as he calls himself, whose clients include the restaurants Daniel and Cafe Boulud, loved lime green. His arrangements, which start at $350, are known for their leaves as much as for their flowers. His Upper East Side shop is paneled in lime-color enamel, and his wardrobe also has verdant touches. Mr. Guigni said the color reminds him of the citrus hues of his native Provence.

Long before Palm Beach colors became the shades of the season, Olivier Guigni, a floral artist, as he calls himself, whose clients include the restaurants Daniel and Cafe Boulud, loved lime green. His arrangements, which start at $350, are known for their leaves as much as for their flowers. His Upper East Side shop is paneled in lime-color enamel, and his wardrobe also has verdant touches. Mr. Guigni said the color reminds him of the citrus hues of his native Provence.
''If I don't have green around me, I'm not happy,'' he said, shrugging. ''Next year, when it's not in fashion, I'll still love lime green.''

Here, Mr. Guigni wears a four-ply lime green cashmere sweater by Lucien Pellat Finet, made for him by the designer, a friend, as a birthday gift. (The sweater can be custom-ordered through Barneys or Jeffrey, 449 West 14th Street, for about $1,600.) Mr. Guigni pairs it with New Balance acid-green sneakers from Paragon (they are no longer available, but for $79.99 you can buy neon-green Alpine Moc sneakers by Merrell at some David Z stores ) and technogabardine pants by Prada ($410) in brown, a color that he prefers to black. ''Black is too easy,'' he said. ''I'm always looking for a challenge, whether it's the way I dress or with flowers.''
